I also have bone mets and started on Zometa and now I am on Xgeva which is just a shot. Let us know what you decide on. Love to all.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 08:32AM mindfulness wrote: "Should I opt for a mastectomy...." Newreality - I feel for you since I am also struggling with this very same dilemma. I have gone back and forth for the past 6 months trying to come to a decision. My burden of disease is low and was NED this past year, until 2 weeks ago, when an MRI showed cancer is back in the breast where original tumor was removed 2 years ago (I was stage iv from the start). There has been some studies about the pros and cons of mastectomy for stage IV patients. Below is the link to one of those studies. www.docguide.com/mastectomy-im... Currently there is also a multicenter clinical study underway addressing this very question. I know in my heart that whatever decision you make it will be the right one for You. Got to believe it and wish you well.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 08:28AM mindfulness wrote: Hello, When you are in LA visiting UCLA, please stop by Simms/Mann UCLA Center for Integrative Oncology (it's on the 5th floor of the Ronald Reagan building). They can put you in touch with the stage IV breast cancer ladies who are also dealing with brain mets. Website is www.simmsmanncenter.ucla.edu Hope they can provide much needed moral support. They also provide tons of other type of support...check it out. Good luck and god bless.

Posts.Title: A Holiday Wish Kim_888 EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: mindfulness wrote: I have been following vaccine trials for sometime now and have participated in one @ Hopkins two years ago. This OPT-822 looks promising (not as involved as some of the other ones i have looked at ) and wanted to share the link for those of you who might be interested in immunotherapy. I am about to start this trial @UCLA and it looks like most of the sites are also recruiting. Here is the link and hope it works: clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NC... The only down side in my opinion is that the study is randomized. You will have two out of three chances to receive OPT-822 and one out of three chances to receive placebo. I guess that's life but worth a try. Love to all. Every time you feel lost, alienated, or cut off from life, or from the world, every time you feel despair, anger, or instability, practice going home.  Mindful breathing is the vehicle that you use to go back to your true home. Thich Nhat Hanh Dx 5/18/2009, 3cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Stage IV and lymph node removal DivineMrsM Hopbird

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 08:36PM mindfulness wrote: I don't post often either but I try to read and learn as much as possible from these boards. The one thing I know is reading posts with familiar names gives me a warm feeling that at least for that day "All is good". Thank you Janis for all your wisdom and compassion. In fact thank you to you all who so openly share your loves, passion, pain, sorrow and triumphs. The other day I came across this passage that has helped me deal with the many losses we've had here and in my support group: Practicing with Loss   Loss is a fact of life. Impermanence is everywhere we look. We are all going to suffer our losses. How we deal with these losses is what makes all the difference. For it is not what happens to us that determines our character, our experience, our karma, and our destiny, but how we relate to what happens.     Lama Surya Das, "Practicing with Loss," Tricycle,  Fall 2003

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 08:36PM mindfulness wrote: Claygirl, The vaccine is paid by the trial. Can the rest (scans/bloodwork...) go under just standard of care as her patient? I don't know if I am making any sense....The nurse in charge of this trial (no longer there) once told me a patient disputed this very issue and finally got approved after six months. I am going back to Johns Hopkins December 1 for my follow-up and will try to see if I can get more info. There must be a way. This is ridiculous.
Posts.Title: Insurance won't pay for clinical trial, a cautionary tale claygirl justjudie

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 01:56PM mindfulness wrote: Please push your onc if this is what you really want. I am currently recovering from my BMX. There are studies showing the benefits of surgery for stage IV patients. The only concern my onc had was the duration of the surgery. She didn't want me to be under for too long so we opted for implants (mine was just under 8 hours). Also, as Gigi pointed out your relationship with the BS is only for that one surgery, your PS is the one you have to like the most! Good luck and may the force be with you!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 10:38AM - edited Mar 16, 2012 10:52AM by mindfulness So sorry to hear about the progression...there is a topic under Afinitor 2012 that has good info about Afinitor. My insurance also denied my appeal (twice)! In CA we have a recourse to appeal to the State insurance commission for review and only then the insurance approved me. It takes time but worth a try. I know the drug maker Novartis also has a process to help pay for the drug ( the application is on thread). I will look for it and PM you. Please let me if you need any help. Best to you. Drug company's link for assistance posted by Chickadee: novartisoncology.us/assets/PAN...
